MediaQueryList.summary: A MediaQueryList object stores information on a media query applied to a document, with support for both immediate and event-driven matching against the state of the document.

remarks.para: You can create a MediaQueryList by calling on the object. The resulting object handles sending notifications to listeners when the media query state changes (i.e., when the media query test starts or stops evaluating to true).

This is very useful for adaptive design, since this makes it possible to observe a document to detect when its media queries change, instead of polling the values periodically, and allows you to programmatically make changes to a document based on media query status.

MediaQueryListAddListener.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The deprecated addListener() method of the
interface adds a listener to the
MediaQueryListener that will run a custom callback function in response to
the media query status changing.

remarks.para:
In older browsers MediaQueryList did not yet inherit from ,
so this method was provided as an alias of .
Use addEventListener() instead of addListener() if it is
available in the browsers you need to support.

MediaQueryListChange.summary: The change event of the interface fires when the status of media query support changes.

MediaQueryListMatches.summary:
The matches read-only property of the
interface is a boolean value that returns
true if the currently matches the media query list,
or false if not.

remarks.para:
You can be notified when the value of matches changes by watching for the
event to be fired at the
MediaQueryList.

MediaQueryListMatches.value:
A boolean value that is true if the
currently matches the media query list; otherwise, it's false.

MediaQueryListMedia.summary:
The media read-only property of the
interface is a string representing a
serialized media query.
MediaQueryListMedia.value: A string representing a serialized media query.

MediaQueryListRemoveListener.summary:

remarks.para:
